@article{10.1145/226643.226644,
author = {Selman, Bart and Kautz, Henry},
title = {Knowledge compilation and theory approximation},
year = {1996},
issue_date = {March 1996},
publisher = {Association for Computing Machinery},
address = {New York, NY, USA},
volume = {43},
number = {2},
issn = {0004-5411},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1145/226643.226644},
doi = {10.1145/226643.226644},
abstract = {Computational efficiency is a central concern in the design of knowledge representation systems. In order to obtain efficient systems, it has been suggested that one should limit the form of the statements in the knowledge base or use an incomplete inference mechanism. The former approach is often too restrictive for practical applications, whereas the latter leads to uncertainty about exactly what can and cannot be inferred from the knowledge base. We present a third alternative, in which knowledge given in a general representation language is translated (compiled) into a tractable formallowing for efficient subsequent query answering.We show how propositional logical theories can be compiled into Horn theories that approximate the original information. The approximations bound the original theory from below and above in terms of logical strength. The procedures are extended to other tractable languages (for example, binary clauses) and to the first-order case. Finally, we demonstrate the generality of our approach by compiling concept descriptions in a general frame-based language into a tractable form.},
journal = {J. ACM},
month = mar,
pages = {193224},
numpages = {32},
keywords = {Horn clauses, efficient reasoning methods, knowledge compilation, knowledge-base optimization, query evaluation, theory approximation}
}

relationTypes.name: No Poly, Unknown Quasi
relationTypes.label: \not\leq_p, ?\leq_q
relationTypes.description: No polynomial transformation exists but quasi-polynomial might.

relationTypes.name: Both Unknown
relationTypes.label: ?\leq_p, ?\leq_q
relationTypes.description: Unknown whether any sub-exponential transformation exists

smoothness.label: Smoothness
smoothness.description: All disjuncts mention the same variables

read-once.label: Read-Once
read-once.description: Each variable appears at most once on any path

CO.label: Consistency
CO.description: Check if the formula is satisfiable

VA.label: Validity
VA.description: Check if the formula is a tautology

CE.label: Clausal Entailment
CE.description: Check if a clause is entailed

IM.label: Implicant
IM.description: Find an implicant of the formula

EQ.label: Equivalence
EQ.description: Check logical equivalence of two formulas

SE.label: Sentential Entailment
SE.description: Check if one formula entails another

CT.label: Model Counting
CT.description: Count the number of satisfying assignments

matrix.description: The existence of polysize knowledge compilation functions for clausal entailment implies the collapse of the polynomial hierarchy. Also, note that $d$-$DNNF$ supports a polynomial-time clausal entailment test. If $CNF$ could be polynomial-time transformed to $d$-$DNNF$, then we could perform a clausal entailment test with any $CNF$ sentence by transforming it to a $d$-$DNNF$ clause.
PICNF in polynomial time. If CNFDNF in quasipolynomial time, then PIDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts PIDNF being no-quasi.

The existence of polysize knowledge compilation functions for clausal entailment implies the collapse of the polynomial hierarchy. Also, note that $DNNF$ supports a polynomial-time clausal entailment test. If $CNF$ could be polynomial-time transformed to $DNNF$, then we could perform a clausal entailment test with any $CNF$ sentence by transforming it to a $DNNF$ clause.
PICNF in polynomial time. If CNFFBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PIFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts PIFBDD being no-quasi.
IPDNF in polynomial time. If CNFIP in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi.
MODSDNF in polynomial time. If CNFMODS in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $CNF$ is a subset of $NNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time. If CNFOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then CNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFFBDD being no-quasi.
It is well-known that some $CNF$ formulas (i.e. $\neg PARITY_n=\neg\bigoplus_{i=1}^n x_i$) have exponentially many prime implicants.
OBDDFBDD in polynomial time. If CNFOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then CNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFFBDD being no-quasi.
OBDD$_<$d-DNNF in polynomial time. If d-DNNFCNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$CNF being no-quasi.
OBDD$_<$d-DNNF in polynomial time. If d-DNNFDNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$DNF being no-quasi.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, d-DNNF is a subset of DNNF, so a polynomial transformation is trivial.

$d$-$DNNF$s can polynomially represent the disjunction of two functions with conflicting variable orders, which forces $FBDD$s to grow exponentially to track the state of both orders within a single "read-once" path.
IPDNF in polynomial time. If d-DNNFIP in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFDNF being no-quasi.
The function $ANY_n=\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $d-DNNF$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.
d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to NNF.
OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time. If d-DNNFOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi.
PICNF in polynomial time. If d-DNNFPI in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFCNF being no-quasi.
OBDDFBDD in polynomial time. If d-DNNFOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi.
IPDNF in polynomial time. If DNFCNF in quasipolynomial time, then IPCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts IPCNF being no-quasi.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $DNF$ is a subset of $DNNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
IPDNF in polynomial time. If DNFFBDD in quasipolynomial time, then IPFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts IPFBDD being no-quasi.
It is well-known that some $DNF$ formulas (i.e. $PARITY_n=\bigoplus_{i=1}^n x_i$) have exponentially many prime implicates.
MODSCNF in polynomial time. If DNFMODS in quasipolynomial time, then DNFCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts DNFCNF being no-quasi.
DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from DNF to NNF.
OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time. If DNFOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then DNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts DNFFBDD being no-quasi.
PICNF in polynomial time. If DNFPI in quasipolynomial time, then DNFCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts DNFCNF being no-quasi.
OBDDFBDD in polynomial time. If DNFOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then DNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts DNFFBDD being no-quasi.
DNFDNNF in polynomial time. If DNNFCNF in quasipolynomial time, then DNFCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts DNFCNF being no-quasi.
d-DNNFDNNF in polynomial time. If DNNFDNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFDNF being no-quasi.
d-DNNFDNNF in polynomial time. If DNNFFBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi.
DNFDNNF in polynomial time. If DNNFIP in quasipolynomial time, then DNFIP in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts DNFIP being no-quasi.
d-DNNFDNNF in polynomial time. MODSFBDD in polynomial time. If DNNFMODS in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $DNNF$ is a subset of $NNF$, so a polynomial transformation is trivial.
d-DNNFDNNF in polynomial time. OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time. If DNNFOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi.
DNFDNNF in polynomial time. PICNF in polynomial time. If DNNFPI in quasipolynomial time, then DNFCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts DNFCNF being no-quasi.
d-DNNFDNNF in polynomial time. OBDDFBDD in polynomial time. If DNNFOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi.
OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time. If FBDDCNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$CNF being no-quasi.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, FBDD is a subset of d-DNNF, so a polynomial transformation is trivial.
OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time. If FBDDDNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$DNF being no-quasi.
FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from FBDD to DNNF.
IPDNF in polynomial time. If FBDDIP in quasipolynomial time, then FBDDDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts FBDDDNF being no-quasi.
MODSOBDD$_<$ in polynomial time. If FBDDMODS in quasipolynomial time, then FBDDOBDD$_<$ in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts FBDDOBDD$_<$ being no-quasi.
FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from FBDD to NNF.
OBDD$_<$OBDD in polynomial time. If FBDDOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then FBDDOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts FBDDOBDD being no-quasi.
PICNF in polynomial time. If FBDDPI in quasipolynomial time, then FBDDCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts FBDDCNF being no-quasi.
The hidden weighted bit function has a lower-bounded $OBDD$ representation of $\Omega(2^{n/4})$, while an $FBDD$ for the same function has a size of only $O(n^2)$

Consider the $DNF$ formula $\Pi_n= igvee_{i=0}^{n-1}(x_{2i} \wedge x_{2i+1})$. This formula is in prime implicants form and each clause in $\Pi_n$ is an essential prime implicant of it. Hence its negation $
eg\Pi_n\in IP$.

Since the early work of Quine, we know that the number of essential prime implicates of a formula is a lower bound on the number of clauses that can be found in any $CNF$ representation of it. However, since $\Pi_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicants, $
eg\Pi_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicates, so any $CNF$ representation of $
eg\Pi_n$ must have at least $2^n$ clauses.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $IP$ is a subset of $DNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from IP to DNNF.

Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}	o\{0,1\}$ so $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=0 \iff I 	ext{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$. It can be shown that for certain values of $k$ (dependent on $n$), every $FBDD$ representation of $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}$ has exponential size. This is the negation of the clique detection function. However, it can be shown that $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}$ has $O(n^3)$ prime implicates, which implies that not every $IP$ formula cannot be converted to $FBDD$ in quasi-polynomial-time.
The function $ANY_n=\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $IP$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.
IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from IP to NNF.
OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time. If IPOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then IPFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts IPFBDD being no-quasi.
PICNF in polynomial time. If IPPI in quasipolynomial time, then IPCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts IPCNF being no-quasi.
OBDDFBDD in polynomial time. If IPOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then IPFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts IPFBDD being no-quasi.

A Shannon tree for any for any $MODS$ formula can be generated in polynomial time. The set of all paths from the root of the tree to any 0-leaf can be read as a $CNF$ representation of the formula, so $MODS$ is converted to $CNF$.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $MODS$ is a subset of $d-DNNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $MODS$ is a subset of $DNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
MODS transforms to DNF in polynomial time. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to DNNF.
MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time. OBDD$_<$ transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to FBDD.
The Quine-McCluskey algorithm generates an $IP$ formula in polynomial time.
MODS transforms to DNF in polynomial time. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to NNF.
A Shannon tree for any for any $MODS$ formula following any order $<$ can be generated in polynomial time. This tree can be reduced into a corresponding $OBDD_<$ in polynomial time.
MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to OBDD.
DNFNNF in polynomial time. If NNFCNF in quasipolynomial time, then DNFCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts DNFCNF being no-quasi.
CNFNNF in polynomial time. If NNFd-DNNF in polynomial time, then CNFd-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFd-DNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi.
CNFNNF in polynomial time. If NNFDNF in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi.
CNFNNF in polynomial time. If NNFDNNF in polynomial time, then CNFDNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi.
d-DNNFNNF in polynomial time. If NNFFBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi.
CNFNNF in polynomial time. IPDNF in polynomial time. If NNFIP in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi.
CNFNNF in polynomial time. MODSDNF in polynomial time. If NNFMODS in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi.
d-DNNFNNF in polynomial time. OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time. If NNFOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi.
CNFNNF in polynomial time. If NNFPI in quasipolynomial time, then CNFPI in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFPI being no-quasi.
d-DNNFNNF in polynomial time. OBDDFBDD in polynomial time. If NNFOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi.
$PARITY_n=\bigoplus_{i=1}^n x_i$ has linear size $OBDD_<$ representations but only exponential size $CNF$ representations.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to d-DNNF.
$PARITY_n=\bigoplus_{i=1}^n x_i$ has linear size $OBDD_<$ representations but only exponential size $DNF$ representations.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to DNNF.
OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to FBDD.
IPDNF in polynomial time. If OBDD$_<$IP in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$DNF being no-quasi.
MODSCNF in polynomial time. If OBDD$_<$MODS in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$CNF being no-quasi.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to NNF.
PICNF in polynomial time. If OBDD$_<$PI in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$CNF being no-quasi.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $OBDD_<$ is a subset of $OBDD$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $PI$ is a subset of $CNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

Consider the $CNF$ formula $\Sigma_n= igwedge_{i=0}^{n-1}(x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1})$. This formula is in prime implicates form and each clause in $\Sigma_n$ is an essential prime implicate of it. Hence its negation $
eg\Sigma_n\in PI$.

Since the work of Quine, we know that the number of essential prime implicants of a formula is a lower bound on the number of terms that can be found in any $DNF$ representation of it. However, since $\Sigma_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicates, $
eg\Sigma_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicants, so any $DNF$ representation of $
eg\Sigma_n$ must have at least $2^n$ clauses.

Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ so $\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=1 \iff I \text{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$. This is the clique detection function. It can be shown that for certain values of $k$ (dependent on $n$), every $FBDD$ representation of $\Sigma_{n,k}$ has exponential size. However, it can be shown that $\Sigma_{n,k}$ has $O(n^3)$ prime implicants, and hence not every $PI$ formula cannot be converted to $FBDD$ in quasi-polynomial-time.
IPDNF in polynomial time. If PIIP in quasipolynomial time, then PIDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts PIDNF being no-quasi.
The function $ANY_n=\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $PI$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.
PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time. CNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from PI to NNF.
OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time. If PIOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then PIFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts PIFBDD being no-quasi.
OBDDFBDD in polynomial time. If PIOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PIFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts PIFBDD being no-quasi.
OBDD$_<$OBDD in polynomial time. If OBDDCNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$CNF being no-quasi.
OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to d-DNNF.
OBDD$_<$OBDD in polynomial time. If OBDDDNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$DNF being no-quasi.
OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to DNNF.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $OBDD$ is a superset of $FBDD$. Therefore a polynomial time transformation is trivial.
OBDD$_<$OBDD in polynomial time. IPDNF in polynomial time. If OBDDIP in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$DNF being no-quasi.
MODSOBDD$_<$ in polynomial time. If OBDDMODS in quasipolynomial time, then OBDDOBDD$_<$ in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDDOBDD$_<$ being no-quasi.

OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to NNF.

The function $\bigwedge_{i=1}^n(x_i\Leftrightarrow y_i)$ has an $OBDD_<$ representation of size polynomial in $n$ whenever $<$ satisfies $x_1<y_1<...<x_n<y_n$ but exponential in $n$ if $<$ satisfies $x_1<x_2<...<x_n<y_1<y_2<...<y_n$
OBDD$_<$OBDD in polynomial time. PICNF in polynomial time. If OBDDPI in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$CNF being no-quasi.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Sigma_n = \bigwedge_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula describes evaluating where given each pair $x_{2i}$ and $x_{2i+1}$, at least one of must be true. It is the dual to the Pairwise DNF.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Pi_n = \bigvee_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \wedge x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula describes evaluating where after pairing $x_{2i}$ and $x_{2i+1}$, at least one pair must have both be true. It is the dual to the Pairwise CNF.

separatingFunctions.name: Parity function
separatingFunctions.description: $O_n = \bigoplus_{i=0}^{n-1} x_i$ has linear size $OBBD_<$ representations but exponential size CNF and DNF representations.

separatingFunctions.name: $OR_n = \bigvee_{i=1}^{n} x_i$
separatingFunctions.description: Separates languages that compactly represent disjunctions from those that cannot.

separatingFunctions.name: Clique Detection Instances
separatingFunctions.description: Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ so $\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=1 \iff I \text{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$.
